ygData.subject: Re: Ok next silly question
ygData.msgSnippet: If it was just me, I would probably switch servers without hesitation. Unfortunately, there s me, my lover, and our best friends (another couple). I can
ygData.messageBody:
If it was just me, I would probably switch servers without
hesitation. Unfortunately, there's me, my lover, and our best friends
(another couple). I can discuss it with them, but I'm not sure how
they would feel about leaving Brell. I think the four of us are in a
similar mindframe to dig in our heels and find the people to get it
going rather than evac out to another server and start (sigh) all
over again.

And, ultimately, I know what one would say to the idea of ditching
his lvl 31 wizard. I know how I feel about abandoning my beloved
Grackk, source of much joy and aggravation (damn ogres level up
slower than you can possibly imagine).

However. I will discuss it with everyone and see what everybody has
to say about it.

Owen

PS and thanks for all the encouragement :)


--- In EQ_rainbow@egroups.com, Vince Bowes <vbowes@s...> wrote:
>
> Owen
>
> I can only echo Chris's point here...I had a 17th level druid on
Tribunal whom
> I loved dearly, but I haven't regretted switching servers to join
Mystic
> Alliance. I levelled back up with two new characters in no time,
and the gay
> friendly atmosphere of MA truly enhances the experience of EQ.
Perhaps you
> could consider beginning an alt on Rodcet to try it out? I doubt
you would
> regret it!
>
> Vince
> Ysanna (soon to be surnamed....stay tuned!)
>
> Christopher Howe wrote:
>
> > Hey Owen,
> >
> > Yay and congratulations for your fight of the good fight. I
myself was
> > recently witness to a barrage of "faggot" comments here on
Rodcet. All I
> > do now is report and petition.
> >
> > Do however consider coming on over to the Mystic Alliance on
Rodcet. I was
> > wary at first too (having a 15th level Shadowknight, which to me
then was
> > the be-all-to-end-all of leveling) because of my hard work, but
after
> > switching and joining up, I realized how much fun it can be to
have a whole
> > guild of gay and gay friendly people to play with ... plus we
have guild
> > events and players which will both help you reach your former
level in no
> > time.
> >
> > I completely understand if you still don't want to switch, but
trust me, it
> > could really be worth your time to at least create a character
over here
> > and check us out.
> >
> > -Chris
> > Vargyr Calusczinelor
> >
> > At 09:16 AM 12/23/00 +0000, you wrote:
> > >Thanks to everyone who responded to my posting. I'm sad to see
that
> > >there are, apparently, so few gay/lesbian players on Brell; or at
> > >least who are also a member of this eGroup.
> > >
> > >My friends and I *don't* want to change servers, so we are
> > >considering starting our own gay/lesbian guild on Brell. The
problem
> > >is, there aren't enough of us.
> > >
> > >I know the process for starting a guild. My qustion is, for
those of
> > >you involved in Nameless Love or Mystic Alliance, how did you
get 10
> > >people? Did you advertise in general (such as in a forum) or did
you
> > >just happen to know 10 other gay/lesbian EQ players, or, well...
how
> > >did it come together.
> > >
> > >Considering what I'm finding to be a generally gay-intolerant
> > >attitude on EQ, I hesitate to start a forum thread about a new
gay
> > >guild or sit around on the chat server hoping 9 other gay people
show
> > >up who want to start a guild.
> > >
> > >I'm 33. I started RPG-ing in 1980 with D&D and Gamma World. I was
> > >away from RPG's for many years and even now EQ is my only RPG
outlet.
> > >I played Magic: The Gathering for a while but it simply became
too
> > >frickin expensive and, to me, pointless. When? When did the
> > >word "gay" become -- in the gaming crowd (which now seems to be
made
> > >up of teeming hordes of 13 yr old boys with a lot of their
parents'
> > >money and No Clue) -- synonymous
> > >with "lame", "stupid", "useless", "weak" and just about any and
every
> > >other negative adjective?
> > >
> > >I spent 15 minutes in Oasis of Marr the other day riding the
virtual
> > >ass of some lame k3wl d00d because he made the /shout "Somebody
come
> > >kill this gay SG please!" I proceeded to riddle him with
questions,
> > >in /shout, such as "How do you know he is gay?" "Does he mince
when
> > >he walks?" "Is his name in lavender or pink over his head?" "Is
his
> > >name Bruce?" "Is he listening to the Village People?" Etc., etc.
> > >While my very tongue in cheek and often virulent replies ilicited
> > >some laughs, several people /shout-ed back stuff like "eww"
> > >and "that's gross". Mainly because initially the player's
response to
> > >me was "Because he'll rip you a new asshole". My response to that
> > >was "Well my boss does that and I'm pretty sure he's a breeder".
> > >
> > >I was under the impression that tolerance was on the upswing, in
> > >general anyway. It seems like on EQ that isn't the case. Is this
> > >server specific or do any of the rest of you have problems with
this?
> > >
> > >Owen
> > >Grackk 16th lvl Ogre Shadowknight
> > >Talsen 9th level Barbarian Shaman
> > >Brell Serilis server
> > >
> > >
> >
